class.name: SiOPMOperatorParams
class.brief_description: Container for processing operator parameters within [SiOPMChannelParams].
class.description: Stores parameters for a single FM operator, including envelope (ADSR), pitch, and modulation settings. These parameters control the behavior of an oscillator within the FM synthesis pipeline.

members.member: Controls how strongly LFO amplitude modulation (tremolo) affects this operator. Valid range is [code]0-3[/code]. A value of [code]0[/code] disables amplitude modulation, while higher values increase the modulation depth.
Attack rate of the envelope. Valid range is [code]0-63[/code]. Higher values result in a faster attack (quicker rise to full volume). A value of [code]63[/code] produces an instant attack.
Decay rate of the envelope. Valid range is [code]0-63[/code]. Controls how quickly the volume drops from the peak to the sustain level after the attack phase. Higher values produce faster decay.

Fine detuning factor. Valid range is [code]0-7[/code]. Applies a small pitch offset based on a lookup table, typically used for FM synthesis richness. The actual pitch offset varies with the key code (note).
Coarse detuning factor, typically used for pTSS (programmable tone sound source). Valid range is [code]0-3[/code]. Applies a larger pitch shift in 64ths of a semitone increments.

When [code]true[/code], the envelope level resets to zero when a new note is triggered (key-on). When [code]false[/code], the envelope continues from its current level, allowing for smoother transitions between notes.

Fine frequency multiplier with sub-integer precision. The frequency is multiplied by [code]fine_multiple / 128[/code]. Common values are [code]64[/code] (0.5x), [code]128[/code] (1x), [code]256[/code] (2x), etc. Use this for precise frequency ratios in FM synthesis.

When set to a non-zero value, the operator ignores the played note and uses this fixed pitch instead. Useful for creating fixed-frequency effects like kick drums or noise elements within an instrument.

Controls the depth of frequency modulation applied to this operator. Valid range is [code]0-7[/code]. A value of [code]5[/code] is the standard FM modulation depth. Higher values increase the modulation intensity.
Starting phase of the waveform when a note is triggered. Used to control the initial position in the wave cycle. A value of [code]-1[/code] means no phase reset occurs on key-on.

Controls how the operator's volume changes with pitch. Valid range is [code]0-3[/code]. At [code]0[/code], volume is constant across all notes. Higher values cause higher notes to become progressively quieter, simulating the natural behavior of acoustic instruments where high frequencies tend to have less energy.

Controls how the envelope speed changes with pitch. Valid range is [code]0-3[/code]. At [code]0[/code], envelope rates are constant across all notes. Higher values cause higher notes to have faster envelopes (shorter attack, decay, and release times), simulating the natural behavior of acoustic instruments.

Integer frequency multiplier. Valid range is [code]0-15[/code]. The operator's frequency is multiplied by this value (with [code]0[/code] treated as [code]0.5[/code]). Used to set harmonic relationships between operators in FM synthesis.
When [code]true[/code], this operator produces no sound output. Useful for temporarily disabling an operator without changing other parameters.
Determines which pitch-to-frequency conversion table is used. Different table types support different tuning systems and frequency ranges.
Determines the waveform shape used by this operator. Must be one of the [enum SiONPulseGeneratorType] values. Common types include sine, square, sawtooth, and various FM-specific waveforms.

Release rate of the envelope. Valid range is [code]0-63[/code]. Controls how quickly the volume fades to silence after the note is released. Higher values produce faster release. A value of [code]63[/code] produces an instant release.

Enables SSG-EG (Software-controlled Sound Generator Envelope Generator) mode, which modifies the ADSR envelope behavior to create repeating or shaped envelopes. Must be one of the [enum SSGEnvelopeControl] values. Values [code]0-7[/code] disable SSG-EG, while [code]8-17[/code] enable various looping and shaping modes.

Sustain level of the envelope. Valid range is [code]0-15[/code]. Defines the volume level maintained after the decay phase while the note is held. A value of [code]0[/code] is maximum volume (no attenuation), while [code]15[/code] is silent.

Sustain rate of the envelope (also known as secondary decay). Valid range is [code]0-63[/code]. Controls how quickly the volume decays during the sustain phase. A value of [code]0[/code] means the sustain level is held indefinitely.

Overall output level (volume) of the operator. Valid range is [code]0-127[/code]. A value of [code]0[/code] is maximum volume, while higher values attenuate the output. Each increment reduces volume by approximately 0.75 dB.

Number of stacked oscillator voices for super/unison effects. Valid range is [code]1-16[/code]. A value of [code]1[/code] is a normal single oscillator. Higher values create a thicker, chorus-like sound by layering multiple detuned copies.
Detune spread amount for super/unison voices. Valid range is [code]0-1000[/code]. Controls how much the stacked voices are detuned from each other. Higher values create a wider, more detuned sound.

Stereo spread amount for super/unison voices. Valid range is [code]0-100[/code]. A value of [code]0[/code] places all voices in the center (mono), while [code]100[/code] spreads them fully across the stereo field.

constants.constant: SSG envelope control is disabled. Values [code]0[/code] through [code]7[/code] all mean that.
Repeat the ADSR envelope upon the volume reaching zero.
SSG envelope control is enabled, but the ADSR envelope is executed as is.
Repeat the ADSR envelope forward and backward, reversing the direction when the volume reaches zero or maximum.
Execute the ADSR envelope as is, then stay at the maximum volume.
Same as [constant SSG_REPEAT_TO_ZERO], but the direction is inverted.
Same as [constant SSG_IGNORE], but the direction is inverted.
Same as [constant SSG_REPEAT_SHUTTLE], but the direction is inverted.
Same as [constant SSG_ONCE_HOLD_HIGH], but the direction is inverted.
Custom mode that holds at the maximum volume throughout.
Custom mode that holds at the zero volume throughout.
Total number of available SSG envelope control modes.
